Jim O'Flaherty, Jr. wrote:

>Colin,
>
>You wrote:
> > It occured to me that real world neural nets exist in 3D due to 
>physical constr[ai]nts - there are only 3 spa[t]ial dimensions!
>
>I have not studied the biology of neurons enough to be very confident of 
>this speculation.  I think *time* might be another dimension of physical 
>neurons.  In other words, there are likely nuances in a physical 
>neuron's firing and the *timing of the receptivity* of a 
>related/connected neuron that had some level of influence on the 
>evolution of the neurons and organ.
>
I read that neurons have been observed to briefly set up connection 
pathways across large regions of the brain only for that pathway to 
never be observed again. When I read this I thought of  how a connection 
is made when you make a phone call (or make a TCP connection on the 
internet), the infrastructure is a physical one but there is no single 
wire going from one end of the connection to the other, the connection 
is a virtual or logical one. But the fact remains that the brain exists 
in 3 spatial dimensions and that any extra functionality that helps 
overcome this limitation, such as virtual connections, is still limited 
by this fact. So staying with the phone system analogy, if neuron's are 
acting as switches on a virtual connection then they cannot be 
simultaneously re-used for another connection. Ok so packet switching is 
another way to get more use out of a communications network, but there 
are still limitations to how many virtual connections can be maintained. 
So are biological NN's acting like a packet switching network or a 
connection based one? Are spikes perhaps part of a 'control' channel 
that is 'in-band' with the 'data' channel - like in the old days when 
you could trick payphones by emitting various tones into the handset.

Colin
